Article.Abstract: In the present study, a systematic analysis of the influenza (Flu) PR8 determinants recognized by H-2b mice was undertaken. A single Db-restricted immunodominant epitope (NP(366)) was previously known in this system. Twenty-three different Flu PR8-derived peptides that bound either Kb or Db molecules in vitro were identified. Sixteen were immunogenic following peptide immunization of C57BL/6 mice, yet CTL induced by peptide immunization recognized PR8-infected target cells only in the case of the NP(366) and NS2(114) epitopes. Similarly, CTL responses following whole-PR8 virus immunization were detected only for the same two determinants. CTL recognizing these dominant epitopes had high avidity for peptide-pulsed target cells, with 5 to 200 pM of peptide required for 30% specific lysis. In contrast, most (80%) of the remaining epitopes were recognized with lower avidity (30% effective concentration in the range of 0.4-50 nM). Repeated in vitro stimulation of primary CTL cultures revealed one additional Kb-restricted epitope (M1(128)). This peptide bound Kb with high affinity (4.6 nM) and induced CTL that effectively recognized PR8-infected cells. These results suggest that 1) this epitope is produced by natural processing in relatively high amounts and 2) low precursor frequency might be related to the subdominant status of the M1(128) epitope. Taken together, these results illustrate the crucial contributions of MHC-binding capacity, and T cell repertoire availability, to the shaping of the repertoire of CTL specificities for Flu Ag virus.
Article.ArticleTitle: Immunodominance analysis of CTL responses to influenza PR8 virus reveals two new dominant and subdominant Kb-restricted epitopes.
Article.Affiliations: R.W. Johnson Pharmaceutical Research Institute, San Diego, CA 92121, USA.
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Animals; Cytotoxicity, Immunologic; H-2 Antigens(immunology ); Immunodominant Epitopes; Influenza Vaccines(immunology ); Mice; Mice, Inbred C57BL; Orthomyxoviridae(immunology ); Peptides(chemistry; immunology ); T-Lymphocytes, Cytotoxic(immunology )

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Immunization mixture contained 140 μg helper epitope HBVc128-140. 2-3 weeeks after immunization, splenocytes were harvested and restimulated in vitro. Splenocytes were stimulated for 7 days in the presence of 10μg/ml peptide.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Percentage of specific lysis was converted to LU30/10^6 cells for comparison among experiments. A CTL response ≥ 2 LU30 was considered positive. The peptide concentration required for 30% specific lysis (EC30) was 5.7 pM.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: 2-3 weeeks after immunization, splenocytes were harvested and restimulated in vitro. Splenocytes were stimulated for 7 days in the presence of 10μg/ml peptide.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: PR8-infected target cells are efficiently lysed by PR8-immunized mice splenocytes subsequently stimulated in vitro with this peptide. Percentage of specific lysis was converted to LU30/10^6 cells for comparison among experiments. A CTL response ≥ 2 LU30 was considered positive.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Immunization mixture contained 140 μg helper epitope HBVc128-140. 2-3 weeeks after immunization, splenocytes were harvested and restimulated in vitro. Splenocytes were stimulated twice for 7 days in the presence of 10μg/ml peptide.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Even when after one round of in vitro stimulation, the CTL activity was low, after secondary in vitro restimulation a good recognition was observed, suggesting it is mediated by low-frequency or low-avidity CTL specificities. The peptide concentration required for 30% specific lysis (EC30) was relatively low, at 3.4 nM. Percentage of specific lysis was converted to LU30/10^6 cells for comparison among experiments. A CTL response ≥ 2 LU30 was considered positive.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: 2-3 weeeks after immunization, splenocytes were harvested and restimulated in vitro. Splenocytes were stimulated for 7 days in the presence of 10μg/ml peptide.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: PR8-immunized mice splenocytes, subsequently stimulated with peptide, are unable to lyse peptide pulsed target cells. Percentage of specific lysis was converted to LU30/10^6 cells for comparison among experiments. A CTL response < 2 LU30 was considered negative.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Immunization mixture contained 140 μg helper epitope HBVc128-140. 2-3 weeeks after immunization, splenocytes were harvested and restimulated in vitro. Splenocytes were stimulated twice for 7 days in the presence of 10μg/ml peptide.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Even when after one round of in vitro stimulation, the CTL activity against PR8-infected targets was not detected, after secondary in vitro restimulation a good recognition was observed, suggesting it is mediated by low-frequency or low-avidity CTL specificities, but that presentation of the peptide occurs. This relates with the subdominant nature of this epitope, which is unable to induce CTL in PR8 infected mice. Percentage of specific lysis was converted to LU30/10^6 cells for comparison among experiments. A CTL response ≥ 2 LU30 was considered positive.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: 2-3 weeeks after immunization, splenocytes were harvested and restimulated in vitro. Splenocytes were stimulated for 7 days in the presence of 10μg/ml peptide.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: PR8-infected target cells are not lysed by PR8-immunized mice splenocytes subsequently stimulated in vitro with this peptide. AssayInformation.AssayComments: PR8-infected target cells are not lysed by peptide-immunized and -stimulated splenocytes, implying a deficient presentation, confirmed by the lack of responses in PR8 infected mice. Percentage of specific lysis was converted to LU30/10^6 cells for comparison among experiments. A CTL response < 2 LU30 was considered negative.

EpitopeRelatedObject.RelatedObjectType: The epitope is an analog of:

Epitope.EpitopeComments: Imported from the TopBank database. This peptide is a artificially modified version of VSV nucleoprotein 52-59 (RGYVYQGL). Position 5 Y was substituted with F to avoid dual radiolabeling. The MHC binding constants for both peptides are indistinguishable.
